div1.p: Whittaker describes the yellow fever experiments and praises Reed and the volunteers.

div1.head: Article: Unsung Heroes, by Ralph Rohrer Whittaker, [1932]
div1.p:
The microbe hunters, unsung and hardly remembered, are now
scarcely better known to the world than the microscopic growths
and creatures they discovered. One of the greatest of these
death-fighters was Walter Reed, head of the Yellow Fever Com-
mission. His is a tale of bold and persistent explorers who
risked their lives-in the interest of science-and for humanity.
Some of them who were too bold have died-done to death by the
immensely small assassins they were studying-and these have passed
to an obscure glory.

The yellow fever germ had killed thousands of our soldiers
in Cuba when Major Reed was called from Washington to give special
attention to its cause and prevention. Day after day Reed and his
co-workers labored with tireless effort-but in vain. However, just
as Grassi discovered the zanzarone carrying malaria because he had
faith, Reed seemed to hear a mysterious voice cry from somewhere
in the wilderness, “Yellow fever is caused by a mosquito!”

At this point began possibly the most audacious self-sacri-
ficing experiments ever recorded in the annals of medical science.
Dr. Carrol, the father of five children, and James Lazear were the
first to expose themselves to the test. In the face of almost cer-
tain death, they submitted to the infection of the mosquito-for
the interest of science-and for humanity! Within forty-eight
hours they were suffering from the effects of yellow fever- and
then found eternal rest. Where are their monuments?

It was the common belief of the great medical minds that un-
sanitary conditions were the cause of yellow fever. Accordingly, Wal-
ter Reed, who was a thorough man, let it be known to the American sol-
diers in Cuba that there was another war being waged-a war for saving
not destroying men. Were there men who would volunteer? Before the
ink was dry on the announcements, four young soldiers reported to
Reed.

He built two small huts- One fouler than the dankest of medi-
eval dungeons. Here three of those courageous men tried to sleep in
filthy cots made up with the bed clothing from yellow fever wards.
For twenty nights they stayed there- at great risk they exploded an
ancient fallacy. Yet where are their monuments?

The other little hut was thoroughly sanitary but contained
deadly mosquitos. Here John Moran,-who knows of him now ?- lay down
to sleep. Three days after the attack of the mosquitos he contracted
yellow fever- fortunately he was saved, but only to live a life of
unmerited obscurity.

Then Walter Reed wrote to his mother: “The prayer that has
been mine for twenty years, that I might be able to do something to
alleviate human suffering, has been granted.” It was magical. At
this stage Walter Reed, in the prime of his life, but tired, so tired-
died; just as the applause of the nation was growing thunderous. “I
am leaving my wife and daughter so little, so little”- he murmured as
he passed away into his last dreams.

Thus this strange band has made a rendezvous, each one, with
his special and particular fate- a group who worked together so that
now there is hardly enough of the yellow fever germ left in the world
to put on the points of six pins. What an enobling thought it is that
UNSUNG HEROES
it is not expedient to wage wars in order to make our heroes. But
that we may proudly boast of these courageous men, who, in peace-
time risked their lives for a most ample and demanding cause- humanity.
